result.execSummary:
The defendant Pedro J. Garcia was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Intimidate Victim/Dissuade Complaints [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.44(2).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).
  • Intimidation of a Victim, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.44(2).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
**89 days credit if revoked**
If Probation or Extended Supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Concurrent with: 15CM304 and 15CM602.

miscConds.notes: No contact with A.S. without her and the agent's consent.
Any conditions/programming per agent including but not limited to Mental Health Evaluation, Domestic Violence Treatment, AODA and follow through.

timeConds.notes: stayed pending successful completion of probation.

IT IS ORDERED:
1. Defendant's 974.06 Wis. Stats., post-conviction motions, however denominated or described, are denied.
2. Defendant's Petitions for Writs of Habeas Corpus are denied.
3. If Defendant submits or tries to file anymore Petitions for a Write of Habeas Corpus, or 974.06, Wis. Stats., motions, and if such petitions or motions show on their face that they are frivolous, any such petitions or motions will simply be ignored and deemed denied.
